author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1711253779}
review:
Pinkman is yet another of literally thousands of console ported 2D retro platformers infesting Steam and lowering the average quality of all video games everywhere.  This particular one of the thousands of competitors is a minimalist precision platformer with one notable gimmick, a limited "flight" mechanic that replaces double jumping and lets you sort of glide a little.  There's also wall jumping, but that's about it.  The game is a particularly difficult precision platformer, which doesn't add much to an extremely mediocre experience. 

One important note is that even though this is an amateur project, it does seem to be sincerely and genuinely made.  I couldn't find any flipped assets, plagiarism or any other kind of insincere actions from the developer, but unfortunately genuine intentions alone are not enough to produce a brilliant PC gaming experience.

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The graphics here are some of the worst, laziest attempt at video game "art" I've ever seen.  It's hard to suggest this game even has graphics.  It's just untextured, basic pixel blocks and blobs, the kind that an infant child might be able to create in 5 minutes on MS Paint.  It's clear the developer didn't even try to produce any real graphics for the game and just phoned it in.  It's unclear why such a lazy approach was taken, whether it may be caused by lack of talent, budget, or motivation to do their job properly.  It also doesn't matter... what matters is that this has resulted in a game with zero visual appeal for gamers.  It's an immediate failure on that measure alone.

There's no option to change the resolution and no useful graphics tweaks.  There's no way to ensure this is running at the native resolution of your display.  There's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

The controls and game handling are notably very floaty and imprecise.  It's janky and unsatisfying to play... and any experienced gamer will tell you, the handling, responsiveness and general gameplay feel of the control scheme must be well polished for this kind of game to succeed.  Unfortunately, this is something the developer seems to have phoned in, with little to no apparent gameplay testing or polish done.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the game unplayable for differently-abled gamers, left handed gamers or gamers using AZERTY or other international keyboard layouts.  

Because this is designed for consoles, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the inferior console gaming appliances that the game was designed for.  These are unfortunate compromises and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was a second thought for the console-centric developers.  The game is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for consoles forces upon a game.  Once more, console peasants have made gaming worse for everyone.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Pinkman didn't appeal much to the people who own a copy of the game, either.  It has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the game didn't really capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for beating the 5th level in the game, trivial to get, but less than 29 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the game.  Hardly a success story, gamers just weren't all that interested in the game.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a modest spike in player counts for the game.  But this only happened once, around the same time that trading cards were applied to the game... so this is just card idlers getting their cards and moving on.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

So, should you buy this game?

Pinkman is relatively cheap at $1 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.  This is also competing with over 11,000 free games available on Steam, many of them far better than this paid product.

review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Don't let the 99 cents scare you off, it's not a bad or super short game. It took me 3 and a half hours to 100% the game, which works out to about 33 cents per hour of enjoyment - well worth it. Just make sure you are aware that you are buying a game that will absolutely frustrate the heck out of you until you either figure out a level or get incredibly lucky.

review:
I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Thank you

author: {'steamid': '76561198073305584', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1661605748}
review:
Hello everyone, I am the gorgeously happy G.E.M.Simov, a pink fellow come to run around and tell you about Pinkman.

 Read the full review here (Steam has a character limit): https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/pinkman---a-review

Gameplay

 Ah, Pinkman. That‚Äôs a game, if I‚Äôve ever seen one. You (the Player) are Pinkman, and you are placed in a multitude of levels, each of which has a simple goal for you - get to the exit after opening it.

 Pinkman, being a 2D side-scroller-esque platformer, in the vein of Super Mario Bros, but with the ability to go backwards, presents the Player with simple controls - A to go left, D to go right. The same can be accomplished with the Left arrow key (to go left) and the Right arrow key to go right. To jump, you press the Z key.

 You can also jump off of walls, which requires that you are up against the wall. Being up against a wall - by moving in the direction of the wall even when you are right next to it - you fall more slowly. You slide down the wall, and that‚Äôs when you can perform the wall-jump, by pressing the Z key.

 There are checkpoints, here and there, allowing you to avoid having to redo the entirety of a level when you die. There are hazards, of course, the most common being spike-balls (which are just spikes on the ground that look like an asterix).

 But you‚Äôre not limited to just running and jumping. You can far‚Äì Fly. You can fly (by farting), which allows for some interesting level layouts. There‚Äôs a gauge that fills up while you‚Äôre not flying (but after a short amount of time following a flight), which gauge is used to measure how lengthy your flight can be. It‚Äôs quite short, but there‚Äôs a solution - BEANS (told you you were farting).

 Picking up a bean (by walking through it) refills your flight gauge, allowing you to fly further. As stated, this allows for interesting level layouts. Not only that, but the way the flight mechanic works, you can treat it as a double jump, for it slightly properly you upwards even with just a tap, allowing you to extend a jump by up to 4 times, which provides quite the sensation if done properly.

 There‚Äôre also jump-pads, which act like trampolines, making the Player Character (PC) jump way up high‚Ä¶ Which allows for even more funky business, such as a spike ball on the ceiling above the jump-pad. It is incredibly simple, in concept and execution, but it allows for some tremendously entertaining things when combined with the rest of the ‚Äòsimple‚Äô stuff.

 It really never does get simple, beyond the first three or four levels. It keeps growing more and more complex due to the multiple variables in play. Homing missiles, as an example, are a very funky variable. Are there homing missiles on this relatively simple jumping level? Well, it is no longer relatively simple.

 That‚Äôs how difficulty in this game works. It is forgiving - courtesy of the reasonable checkpoint system - but it is also a bit unforgiving, in the sense that some of the segments in the levels are monstrously hard to get a hang of. But then the Player figures out what they‚Äôre meant to do and then wham, it‚Äôs suddenly simple in appearance.

 It keeps getting more and more complex, which introduces difficulty, but it never becomes conceptually impossible. And, seeing as a concept is what is most needed in platformers - knowing how to deal with the issues - that‚Äôs a very good thing.

 There‚Äôs also a hardmode, but it isn‚Äôt that hard, as it just removes checkpoints. When you‚Äôve gotten good, you‚Äôve gotten good, and you need no checkpoint to really excel. 

 There‚Äôs a slew of mechanics that show up and present more and more challenges, and it‚Äôs all impressively well done. Pinkman, although lacking the ‚ÄòI just enjoy the act of playing‚Äô, really gets close to gameplay design perfection. 3/3

Presentation

 This game‚Äôs opening screen is the title of the game - PINKMAN - and a spectacularly unexpected, wholesome compliment aimed at the player, which states: ‚ÄúHappiness looks gorgeous on you.‚Äù

 That‚Äôs a way to start things off, is it not? Unfortunately, the music accompanying it feels‚Ä¶ Well, quiet. Very, very quiet, even when it‚Äôs the only thing I‚Äôm hearing. That, however, doesn‚Äôt lessen its quality. It‚Äôs some great music, as you might find out the entirety of the game has.

 In fact, there is one track. One track in this game is absolutely breathtaking‚Ä¶ More on that later.

 The SFX of this game are also quite neat. In part because whenever the PC dies, they MIGHT let out the Wilhelm Scream, in part because they‚Äôre very much secondary to the music and are just there to provide a bit more feedback to the Player.

 Sure, it is a pixel-art game, sure, nothing in it is all that complex looking, sure, there‚Äôs little in the way of visual variety with the exception of the color of the background and the color of the foreground, but it‚Äôs enough for me.

 Not only that, but there‚Äôs also a very good, very comprehensive set of tutorials. Every time a new mechanic is introduced, there‚Äôs a line of text - a short one - that informs the Player of the mechanic in question. Some are redundant, because it is obviously a new type of gun, but others are quite important, because there‚Äôs really no way of knowing that going through the rhomboid shape creates a ghost that follows the PC and that the ghost kills the PC if it touches it.

 Wait what do you mean that wasn‚Äôt conveyed? Oh, right, this game treats the Player as a reasonable creature and allows them to uncover things through trial and error. In the ghost case, the important thing that does get pointed out is that it can go through walls, which is something the initial ‚Äògo through rhomboid and die to ghost‚Äô stage of research will not inform the Player.

 I‚Äôm of the opinion that this game has a really good presentation. Sure, it might be possible for it to be better, if the visual fidelity was greater, but I quite appreciate the look of things. It allows for immaculate smoothness and imagination, and that latter thing‚Ä¶ Pinkman‚Ä¶ Pink‚Ä¶ Guy? 3/3

Story

 There is no story, folks. It‚Äôs just a platformer. 0/3

Legendary Point

 Does this game get the legendary point, so craved and wanted by all and none at the same time? When I first laid eyes upon it in the Steam Store, I think I had obtained a coupon for it‚Ä¶ or something along those lines. I see the game ‚ÄòPinkman‚Äô and, due to the fact that, at the time (and still to this day) I was mourning the death of Francis of the Filth, also known as Father Francis, also known as Filthy Frank or Papa Franku, the sight of a Pinkman, who was entirely pink, got my neurons colliding.

 Pinkman is evocative of Pink Guy, a character from the Filthy Frank Show, and one that I greatly appreciate. I suppose that this is one of the reasons why Pinkman is such a special game for me, yet I can not quite explain it to myself. That infantile sensation of hiraeth that has taken over me, in relation to the Filthy Frank Show, can not be the sole reason I‚Äôm willing to give this game the Legendary Point.

 And it isn‚Äôt. The reason I so appreciate Pinkman is, partially, his resemblance of Pink Guy, and partially the soundtrack. It is Synthwave (according to the store-page), but I couldn‚Äôt care less what type of music it is. It is music, it is great, lovely music that really tickles my soul and drags its metaphorical fingers through it, making me ‚Äòooh‚Äô and ‚Äòaah‚Äô in bursts of uncontrollable and inappropriate ecstasy. YES, Pinkman gets the point.

 ‚Ä¶I miss Frank. 1/1

Conclusion

7/10. This is a great game for what it is. It‚Äôs a simple platformer that grows more complex the further on it goes, until, eventually, you beat it without really knowing that you have. I‚Äôd recommend it to everyone, maybe as a game for them to play or as a gift to present to someone - it‚Äôs engaging for an hour, maybe two, and it‚Äôs, as said, very amusing. The music might make you go back to it, too!

 I tuck it under my belt, another shining achievement that I proudly display.

author: {'steamid': '76561198987128858', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1645220459}
review:
An excellent little platformer with tight controls, an chill synthwave soundtrack curtesy of HOME and a decently challenging pack of levels.

PROS:

+The synthwave soundtrack, while not written specifically for the game fits right in with its pixelated artstyle.
+While simple, the artstyle is clear and defined. 
+The controls work smoothly and are responsive. Pinkman feels fluid and fast, which makes dodging hazards a blast.
+There is little to no filler. Something is introduced every five levels which keeps the game fresh and exciting.
+The insanely low asking price.

CONS:

-Some of the pallets are bright and a little garish. It can be hard to see projectiles (such as the machine-gun fire) in some of them, while in others they are much clearer. This inconsistency can make a few levels feel frustrating if you die a lot in them.
-The 100 levels provided, while fun, make the game very short. 

-Lack of settings for control rebinds (or lack of settings in general).

Most of those cons are nitpicks though, and for a 70p game you shouldn't expect everything. Definitely pick this up if you can, as it's an hour or two of pure platforming fun you won't regret.

7/10

review:
Pinkman, it's simple, but great.
Pinkman is a very minimalist platform game in all factors. Obviously it is not a AAA game with millions of dollars invested, it is a game for you to enjoy its simplicity.
His visual made up of few details is really beautiful, it's like an abstract painting with well selected color palettes. The soundtrack is super relaxing, giving the feeling of exploring a world totally unknown and full of surprises. Its gameplay is more basic than a platform game, with few actions, no stress to learn to play, and with a great difficulty for the genre!
Pinkman is for those people who want something new to play, but don't want to spend a lot of money and time, being a great option for you to spend a few hours in a different universe, on a joyful journey to get out of the habit. No history, collectibles and nothing to worry about, just buy, download and be happy playing.


(Extra info: I love Pinkman items in the Steam Points Store)

review:
If you are a fan of the precision platformer genre you are doing yourself a disservice if you don't pick up this game. With incredibly tight controls, and 100 levels that scale in difficulty with pretty much perfect pacing Pinkman is an absolute steal at the price. If you are looking for a small gift for friends who really enjoyed playing through Super Meat Boy or Celeste this is it. The one issue I had with the game is that after a death the colour scheme changes and some of the colour schemes can make it harder to see projectiles. This is a relatively easy fix by just taking an extra death to change the colours again, just a bit of an annoyance if anything.

Overall, I would highly recommend grabbing this game if you are even slightly interested. You'll thank me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044437838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1622619242}
review:
A really fun game. the controls are spot on, the jetpack mechanic is fun, and the level designs are good. I have two major problems with the game though: 
1. the color scheme changes every time you die, and some of the color schemes make it hard to see small projectiles
2. For a precision platformer it was too easy; I was able to beat it in a little over an hour. I was hoping for a greater challenge.
Considering the game is only 99 cents, though, I would say it's well worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982273259', 'num_games_owned': 13627, 'num_reviews': 568, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1607308207}
review:
[h1][b]100 Levels of Pure Awesomeness![/b][/h1]

[i]I was sent this game on the 6th of August, 2018 via Curator and I'm so sorry to the developer that this absolute gem of a game got lost among the heaps of asset flipped garbage that I'm continually sent.[/i]

I'm not a huge fan of the 2D platformer genre per say as I tend to find them quite tedious, repetitive and annoying. [b]Pinkman[/b] however is a breath of fresh air, using a variety of cleverly placed traps across 100 well designed levels. This game was not only a ton of fun to play but also very friendly on the old casual gamer making 100% completion possible while also accommodating the veteran platforming gamer with it's unlockable hard mode.

I can't recommend this game enough. It's well worth the asking price.

review:
A precision platformer with above average level design. Its frustrating at times but isn't unfair; you'll want to keep trying a level until you beat it. There's also checkpoints which are placed in spots that actually make sense. I really don't like these 'single death' platormers where you have to go over the entire level again if you die, its too punishing. 

The soundtrack is made up of Royalty-free Synthwave tracks, and the minimalist design suits the game, it doesn't need to be flashy. It takes about an hour to finish and only costs a single euro. Recommended.

review:
Genre:
-Precision platformer

Fit for me:
-My fav genre so perfect fit!

Pros:
-Really clean, minimal aesthetic
-Every time you die, the color palette changes and there are a ton of different options
-Solid use of mechanics; I like the jet pack mechanic and think it was implemented well
-Simple mechanics of jumping and jet-packing done right
-Good job implementing new environmental hazards or mechanics to challenge the player
-Well designed platformer sections w/ generous placement of check-points
-Solid difficulty curve that never feels unfair
-Cheap as balls starting at $1

Cons:
-Very short, I beat the main game in under 90 minutes.
-Not as responsive as top tier platformers
-If you hit the jump button too quickly after landing on a wall, it may not register and so you'll fall down
-Most of the mechanics and overall gameplay has been done before

Thoughts:
-I had a really good time w/ this one.  I bought it during the summer sale this year and am happy w/ the value I got. 
 Yesterday, I saw that the dev just finished a major update, so I thought it was a good time to check it out.  I played through the 100 levels in 2 sittings and it was a really solid experience and I will definitely try out the No Checkpoint Hard Mode sometime soon.  This is an easy one to sit down and enjoy for both casual gamers and veterans alike.  I loved the endless color palettes and thought the jet pack was a neat mechanic that you don't usually see from games in this genre.  The soundtrack was subtle and calming, perfectly capturing the overall tone and feel of the game.

Consensus:
-Solid Game (Tier 3 and makes up 35% of my reviews).  Seriously, it's $1 and a good game, support the dev!

review:
After playing Duck Souls, I decided to play the other two Green Dinosaur games. Starting with Pinkman, I liked it a lot!

Pinkman plays a lot like Duck Souls, but with different physics. Instead of rolling, you can fly/hover, and the general feel of the game is a bit different. Both games are polished and fun, and feel like complete experiences in themselves. Still, they are remarkably similar, where Duck Souls seems like a more experienced dev's take on Pinkman.

I don't necessarily regret playing them both though. Both experiences were fun, and the different level design made them feel unique. If I had to pick between this and Duck Souls, Duck Souls would have my vote. Still, this one's cheaper, and I'd recommend playing both if you're looking for cheap games.

I absolutely recommend Pinkman, but with the caveat that I recommend Duck Souls even more. If you want a good, short platformer, you can't go wrong either way, but Duck Souls has the edge.

review:
A (very) minimalistic platformer, that has tight controls and is fun to play. I expected the difficulty curve to ramp up considerably in the later stages of the game, but the last 50 levels took me exactly the same time as the first 50. A total of 2 hours gameplay is good for the low price - and Pinkman certainly has some replayability.
I would have liked the game to have a timer so I can to try to beat my best runs on a level. It would also be nice to have hard-to-get collectibles on each level for some additional challenge.
In some of the later levels things can get a bit hectic, requiring rapid keyboard input to avoid all sorts of projectiles - in a few of these levels I experienced issues with the left-right cursor keys not being recognized anymore for a split second. I think it is triggered when you accidentally press 3 keys simultaneously. Apart for that, Pinkman is rock solid and great fun to play.

review:
[h1]Score: 6.5/10[/h1]
Gameplay: 7/10
Visuals: 6/10
Audio: 7/10
Story: N/A

[h2]Price/Value: 8/10[/h2]

[h2]Pros:[/h2]
Let me start by saying that, especially for its price, the game itself is pretty good. Decent visuals and great music, as well as fairly good movement. (The "fart" mechanic is a bit weird to get used to but pretty fun once you get the hang of it). A bit short on content, but for a $1 game, that's to be expected. Fairly good level design as well, outside of a few levels that felt gimmicky. I'm also a fan of how the level changes colors each time you die, it makes it feel less repetitive somehow.

[h2]Cons:[/h2]
The collision can be somewhat iffy. There are several occasions where you clearly did not touch a spike, but the game thinks you did, resulting in an unwarranted death. This can be infuriating, especially during sections with tight platforming requirements.

[h2]Conclusion & Thoughts:[/h2]
The levels and gameplay are fine but nothing incredible, but definitely better than expected for the price. The music is also really nice. Could be better, but could certainly be worse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111680039', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1564697426}
review:
Just completed this game , 100% and everything.

If you're looking for a game that's challenging, but not impossible. Fun but will test your skills, then this is a game for you!!

I'll start with the bad (because I like ending things on a good note).

- There was only one real problem, I had with the game. That was sometimes the keys seemed to be sticky. You press jump but your guy would not jump. I did think it may have been me, so I tried different keyboards and my Xbox controller and I had that problem with all of them. Now, don't get me wrong. This was not a game breaking issue, I was still able to play the game and 100% it. It just meant it was annoying at time.

Now for the good.

- The graphics are simple and straight forwards. Yet pretty looking.
- The game play is straight forwards as well. Get yourself from point A to B without dying.
- The level progression is really good. Every 10 levels they add something new, which keeps the game fresh and challenging.
- As I mentioned, it's not impossible but it will test you! By the end, you will feel like you have really accomplished something!
- The sound track is nice, but to be honest. Most of the time I had it muted and was watching Netflix in the background.

That's about it! As I said, I only had one fault with this game. However it was nothing major, didn't ruin the game. Was still enjoyable and I do suggest for anyone that is looking for something fun but short to play through!!

review:
Making a 2D platformer game is a very risky thing, because you're competing against some of the greatest games ever made, swimming in a sea of thousands upon thousands of other platformers and saying: "Hey, look at me, I'm worth playing!"

Sadly, this is one of those titles that will probably be gone in the waves of that sea and be forgotten in time... but melodrama aside, it's a shame, because this game is good, really good, and it's developers have done a fantastic job at making a fun and short game that is totally worth the player's time, but sometimes the competition can crush a game that was most likely as worth playing as them.

It's no masterpiece, that's true, and (for example) sometimes the controls can be a little stiff; but it's a very good, fun experience that won't waste your time if you're willing to give it a chance... 

And it's one dollar, like, come on, man, just try the goddamn game.

review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/]Follow our curator page: [b]IndieGems[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

Pinkman is a colorful, fast-paced, action platformer with a funny skill. What is that funny skill, you ask? Well, your main character is a pinkman who can fart to get a little extra distance or height on that jump. This fart is limited and after discharging, you will need to wait a little bit of time before it recharges. 

The game features 100 levels, with progressively increasing difficulty by the different types of ways to die. The later levels introduce obstacles that are more difficult to step around, as well as tighter jumps and smaller spaces while offering less reaction time.

I usually do not compare games with each other, instead I prefer to talk about the merits of the game as it stands alone. However, this game has more than enough similarities to another that I cannot help but bring it up.

With that being said, if you have N++ (NPLUSPLUS) you have a pretty good idea of what this game is about. Though this game takes away some of the momentum, and does not let you die from falling too far. Otherwise this game is only 100 levels, whereas N++ has 4000+ levels. But then again, this game is 0.99 USD. If you already have N++, you are not getting much more with this game. But if you wanted to play something like N++ but didn't have the spare funds to purchase that one, you should get this one instead.

The game works well with XBox controller, you can move with the left stick and d-pad (yay!) and the four buttons on the right are A for jump, B for fart, X for zooming in and out, and Y for turning the music on/off. X is important if you want to plan out your track, as the game starts zoomed in and you sometimes can't tell where you are and where you want to go. This is especially important in the later levels so you can plan out your path given the more time-sensitive nature of these levels.

Overall, this a good game, and it was developed by one person. The responsive jumping controls of a platformer is an important aspect that is unfortunately put on the back burner of some newer games that focus on flashy visuals instead. This game plays very well with the controller and with the keyboard as well. (I did not play much on the keyboard, only to test it out.)

Like I said above, if you want to get a good feel for N++ but don't have the spare funds, you can start with this game and see. If you like this game and finish it, then crave for more, it will not be too late to move onto the other game, because that one offers a lot more gameplay. For 0.99 USD, this game is totally worth it, and there is just enough interesting variations to keep you going level after level, not to mention the easy to reset if you fail (the game actually does this for you).

As one of my friends pointed out (shout out to @Crimson-Albedo), that this game can have rather dramatic color changes every time you die. The sudden shift, depending on the random next palette that you get, may be a bit harsh on the eyes, and that's really one of the only negative things to say about this game. Perhaps when you die, your pink character sprite sometimes makes a really strange dying sound effect that just does not seem right, but that's more of a personal preference.

I'm gonna talk so much shit about one level that I'd rather decorate that little piece of shit with the big ass ribbon this game ultimately is. Which is to say I'm starting with the [i]positive aspects:[/i]

One of the main aspects about this game that made certain areas get aroused was the price. You definitely can't go wrong with that. On sale it's only 0,49$. Which sure is better than chocolate but only because white chocolate got 6 cents more expensive than it at my local store in the last year. 

I've had my very fair share of platformer over the last year so I pretty much know my preferences and it's definitely a fast paced game like this one. Even the elevator platforming is good in this. Another thing I like in platformers is simple controls taken effective. Which this game does. Literally.

I was first pretty sceptic of the graphics. I mean, woah 8-bit, never seen that. But I've grown at it like a baby at it's index finger now. It also has some good music too. Which by the way, is royalty free, can you believe that?

Going back to older levels only made my experience with it better, I have fond and good memories about how I struggled on that level the first time. Not to say I didn't struggle the second time around. (Not talking about a certain level I talk about later)

There are time based levels, which I generally hate, but they are rather a mechanic here which can and is supposed to be tricked than an inevitable death timer. And that's just one of the reasons why in this game most... all of the deaths feel like my fault.

[i]The highly anticipated bad things:[/i]
First off there's level 29, where you're supposed to fart (similar to a jetpack) while falling down when hitting the button that opens the door to further progress in the level. You can refill your fart with beans to get up again. So far so good. The problem being that as soon as the fart runs out, even if you're only a nanoparticle away from a bean you're fucked. You missed the button? Well, fuck you. You're fucked again. Back to the beginning with you.

But maybe I'm just a noob here. Which, admittedly, happens often.

[i]TL;DR:[/i]
It's an almost perfect bag of platformer. Fast paced. Simple controls. Good graphics. Challenging. Masochistic. But Fair.
Only almost because there's a, for my skills, hard as nails level 29 thrown in randomly.

Anyway. This is a great game, and you should definitely get it as soon as possible.

review:

A nice, interesting and well crafted indie game.
I really enjoyed it.

I just started playing this game and it is pretty cool. The soundtrack is awesome with a very 80's vibe. The gameplay is awesome. If you have played Celeste by Matt Thorson before, you will do just fine at the beginning. 

It's an action plataformer where you have to open doors, turn knobs and so on in order to progress. It is pretty simple but the game has a nice progression on the level design getting it harder each time with new doors to open or things that might kill you, as well as complicated designs that are hard to navigate into.

BTW, fun fact! Watching the video on the store page, when the character does the "second jump" I thought to myself: huh, that looks like a fart. Little did I know that the game developer refeers to it as a fart inside the game. That was nice :)

Great job, great game. Having lots of fun with it!

review:
2D action platformer with 100 levels. The quality of level design is excellent and imaginative, along with tight, responsive controls. New mechanics are introduced regularly and it feels fresh and challenging throughout. It's difficult but you always feel you can succeed with a few more attempts. Each time you die the level changes its colour theme, this doesn't have any significance to the gameplay but it is a nice aesthetic touch. Pinkman is always pink, of course!

There is no settings menu but everything is already set up exactly as you would want it. Steam/Xbox controllers 'just work', the sound volume is set just right and it starts in fullscreen. Alt-Enter to switch to windowed and you can stretch it to any size you like. Controller X button to zoom the level view in/out, Y to toggle music (which is very good). The whole playing experience feels comfortable and satisfying. Other devs could learn a thing or two from this.

Overall I highly recommend Pinkman, and at this price it's just plain rude not to buy it. I do wish I could play it on Linux though.

review:
I personally purchased this game. I reviewed it for my 99 Cent Gaming series.

Wow...I think there has been a gold standard set when it comes to games I've reviewed on my show. Ladies and gentlemen I present to you Pinkman, a very fun masochistic platformer that is in the same vein of Super Meat Boy, N+, and those before it.

There is so much going for this title that being priced at a cool .99 (and cheaper if you get it during the first week) makes it almost criminal to not recommend. Everything from the controls to the gradual increase in difficulty to the introductions of new mechanics and obsticals are all done in a way to only help the player understand what exactly brought them their doom.

Like many platformers of this kind, Pinkman offers very simple controls that support both keyboard and controller. I used controller in this case and the character handled very well and never felt too sensitive or weighty. In addition to moving and jumping you can utilize a jetpack (or "fart" if you perfer) to give an extra boost when trying to make up to other platforms or trying to avoid an explosive death. 

Never once did I feel like a death was cheap or unavoidable, something that could have easily been done to make players try over and over again to pad out play time. Every level I had played through for my review (1-35) felt fair, difficult, and fun which only made me want to keep playing once the video was over.

Altough the graphics are very simplistic, they also help the player to keep focused on the obstacles at hand. There's never a distraction thrown at you from how it's designed. The sound is also amazing and it kept my adrenaline going even when I suffered a round of deaths on a few levels.

If I had to nitpick, I wish there were options for recording how fast you beat a level. Games like this are a speed runners dream, and the lack of a time keeping mechanic just baffles me. Hopefully in a future update this can get added.

I have more to save in the video below, but overall this was a joy to not only discover but to review. Controls were on point, everything seemed polished, and it felt like a game with a purpose. Was this worth the .99 cents: absolutely! In fact, I was in doubt I'd ever find a gold standard when it came to games around this price point. Now I hope that I'll find other games that can reach this level of 99 cent enjoyment. Definitely give this developer your support.
